bird_report.further_information: UK Action Plan was operation until 2012 (http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/_speciespages/159.pdf) and is now superceded by separate conservation planning process at country scale: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/page-6189. Species included in the Section 41 list (England) and Section 42 list (Wales) which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions. bird_report.population_trend_additional_info: Harvey, P.V. & Heubeck, M. 2012. Changes in the wintering population and distribution of Slavonian Grebes in Shetland. British Birds 105: 704-715. Harvey & Nelson note a 400% increase in over-wintering numbers in Orkney & Shetland probably as a result of increase in Icelandic population. This seems to be in a consequence of the increase of the Icelandic breeding population, and in contrast to general stability of numbers recorded in inshore waters elsewhere in the UK. Shetland now holds a higher % of the British wintering popn (c.55%) compared to 20 years ago (<20%) - the the result that the national trend reflect the increases in the northern archipelagos

Also listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 to similar effect.

In England, species included in the Section 41 list which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity in England, when carrying out their normal functions. Also listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 to similar effect.

Legal hunting has therefore been assessed as a potential threat in the absence of data otherwise.

bird_report.further_information: UK Action Plan was operation until 2012 (http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/_speciespages/244.pdf) and is now superceded by separate conservation planning process at country scale: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/page-6189. Species included in the Section 41 list (England) and Section 42 list (Wales) which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions. Also listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 to similar effect.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Breeding Atlas 88-91 estimate was a minimum and related to individuals, as commentary there said it was unclear what proportion were non-breeders. However, WeBS suggest that most wintering birds have departed before April, hence estimate now divided by two to give approximate number of pairs.

Also listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 to similar effect.

Species included in the Section 41 list (England) and Section 42 list (Wales) which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions. Also listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 to similar effect. Northern Ireland Action Plan @ http://www.doeni.gov.uk/niea/lapwingsapmbwebversionapril_05changed.pdf

Species included in the Section 41 list (England) and Section 42 list (Wales) which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions. bird_report.further_information: UK Action Plan was operation until 2012 (http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/_speciespages/587.pdf) and is now superceded by separate conservation planning process at country scale: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/page-6189. Species included in the Section 41 list (England) and Section 42 list (Wales) which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions. Also listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 to similar effect. Northern Ireland Action Plan @ http://www.doeni.gov.uk/niea/roseatetern_pdf.pdf

bird_report.population_sources: Harris, M.P. & Wanless, S. 2004. Common Guillemot Uria aalge. Pp. 350-363. In: Mitchell, P.I., Newton, S., Ratcliffe, N. & Dunn, T.E. (eds.) Seabird populations of Britain and Ireland. T. & A.D. Poyser.
bird_report.population_additional_info: Totals for Guillemot races are derived as follows (following Harris & Wanless 2004). U. aalge albionis is calculated based on all Guillemots in Northern Island are albionis; Guillemots in SW Scotland north to, and including Ailsa Craig are albionis; all Guillemots in England excluding Northumberland are albionis. All other Scottish birds and in Northumberland are U. a. aalge.

bird_report.further_information: UK Action Plan was operation until 2012 (http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/_speciespages/589.pdf) and is now superceded by separate conservation planning process at country scale: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/page-6189. Species included in the Section 41 list (England) and Section 42 list (Wales) which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions. Also listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 to similar effect.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Evidence from multiple sources (BBS, Bird Atlas 07-11, RBBP, nest box schemes) indicate that the breeding population has increased substantially in recent years. However, there is no simple measure of change for this species. Period = 1995-1997.

bird_report.population_sources: Freeman, S.N., Balmer, D.E. & Crick, H.Q.P. 2007. Tawny Owl Survey 2005. BTO News 268: 6–7.
bird_report.population_additional_info: The 2005 BTO survey found 1.42 pairs per occupied tetrad, and found that 63% of tetrads were occupied. Applying these figures to the land area of Britain, excluding the northern and western isles where the species is absent, yields an estimate of about 50,000 breeding pairs. The inherent assumptions are that the survey method enabled detection (or inference) of all pairs in the tetrad, and that pairs detected by observers at the mid-point of a tetrad have a territory that does not extend beyond the tetrad boundary. Both assumptions are arguable but reasonable and the estimate should thus be relatively sound.

pressure_threat.sources: [Threat only] Langston, R.H.W et al. 2007. Nightjar Caprimulgus europaeus and Woodlark Lullula arborea – recovering species in Britain? Ibis 149(Suppl. 2): 250-260 . http://www.avibirds.com/pdf/N/Nachtzwaluw2.pdf. Dolman & Morrison 2012. Temporal change in territory density and habitat quality for Breckland Forest SSSI woodlark and nightjar populations. University of East Anglia report to Forestry Commission.

[Threat only] Langston, R., Drewitt, A. & Liley, D. 2007. Bird conservation and access: coexistence or compromise? British Wildlife 19: 1-9. Mallord, J.W., Dolman, P.M., Brown, A.F. & Sutherland, W.J. 2007. Linking recreational disturbance to population size in a ground-nesting passerine. Journal of Applied Ecology 44: 185-195.

[Threat only] Wright, L.J., Hoblyn, R.A., Green, R.E., Bowden, C.G.R., Mallord, J.W., Surtherland, W.J. & Dolman, P.M. 2009. Importance of climatic and environmental change in the demography of a multi-brooded passerine, the woodlark Lullula arborea. Journal of Animal Ecology 78: 1191–1202.

bird_report.further_information: UK Action Plan was operation until 2012 (http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/_speciespages/80.pdf) and is now superceded by separate conservation planning process at country scale: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/page-6189. Species included in the Section 41 list (England) and Section 42 list (Wales) which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions. Also listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 to similar effect.

bird_report.further_information: UK Action Plan was operation until 2012 (http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/_speciespages/76.pdf) and is now superceded by separate conservation planning process at country scale: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/page-6189. Species included in the Section 41 list (England) and Section 42 list (Wales) which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty under section 40 of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006, to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions.

Species listed under Section 2(4) of The Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 which is used to guide decision-makers such as public bodies, including local and regional authorities, in implementing their duty to have regard to the conservation of biodiversity, when carrying out their normal functions.
